text: American judges should not be prevented
from considering Sharia or any foreign
law for that matter in deciding their
cases that has been the law of the land
for the past 100 years since the Supreme
Court decision in Hilton versus Hyatt US
courts have been considering foreign law
on a regular basis we live in a global
environment we become a global village
marriages and commercial transactions
are crossing borders so courts are
regularly required to take this into
account as it pertains to this movement
so called movement auntie Shelley I
movement adopting legislation around the
country seeking to prevent judges from
considering foreign law or Sharia that
is on its face young unconstitutional it
violates the Supremacy Clause it
violates and implicates the freedom of
religion and exercise of Muslim
Americans and is inconsistent with a
hundred years of jurisprudence now the
main point is that how does Shetty I
actually come into play in an American
court setting I mean the it only comes
into playing too into circumstances
either it comes into play as a foreign
law which would mean that Shetty I is
either a source or a primary source of
law in this foreign country or it's
going to come into play as extrinsic
evidence to help explain something to a
judge in other words to explain an
ambiguity to clarify a mistake to place
a context on the expectations of the
parties at the time of executing a
document or their understanding of the
circumstances surrounding a contract so
it only comes into playing those two
limited circumstances and the
jurisprudence is so clear throughout the
United States is that we only would
recognize a foreign judgment from a
foreign country or consider foreign law
in a US Court only if it comports with
our due process and our public policy in
other words if the decision that was
rendered in a foreign country did not
provide due process that did not have an
impartial tribunal that the parties were
not able to participate freely in the
litigation and that the court did not
have jurisdiction or that anything the
court did would violate our public
policy of course the US Court would not
i SAT and you'll see case after case
throughout the United States where these
cases are fact specific the facts
determine the outcome of the case if the
judge finds it did not violate public
policy he will recognize it if he finds
that it violated public policy he would
set it aside so this is a circumstances
that the jurisprudence is clear that our
constitutional protections are already
in place so these additional
legislations around the country do not
provide any added level of protection
for Americans in fact they get in a way
of implicit constitutional issues such
as freedom of religion and the right to
to contract so this is really the the
crux of what the law is now as an
example there's one example that has
been used continuously by the proponents
of this legislation which is a New
Jersey case which really is not a case
about Sharia it's a case about a judge
failing to comply with New Jersey law
there was an allegation from a wife that
her husband was domestically abusing her
he was having unwanted sexual sexual
relations so during a court proceeding
where the wife sought a restraining
order the husband alleged that under his
religious beliefs he believed genuinely
that he was entitled to engage in sexual
relations with his wife upon demand and
the court decided that there was it
seemed a genuine belief in that which
impacted whether the defendant formed
the intent to commit the crime well of
course the judge mistook in
interpretation of New Jersey law on
appeal the court reversed saying that
there is no necessity for an element of
intent there was a knowing knowledge of
the husband that he was engaging in
unwanted sexual sexual relations
therefore the court reversed and entered
a restraining order our system works the
judges in this country are equipped with
the tools to review the cases on their
facts and only on their facts would they
make these final determinations so in
the end this allegation that chetia is
coming to supplant are our Constitution
is intent with nothing but political
consequences it is it is premise on
targeting a particular religious
community and marginalizing a religious
community and it is clear because the
the statutes are specifically drafted to
target the Muslim community and this
will cause disharmony in our society it
would cause civil rights violations in
